newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan computer makers challenge Cray market charge.
newsitem.headline: Japan computer makers challenge Cray market charge.

text.p: Japanese computer makers said on Tuesday that Japan's supercomputer market is more open than in the United States, challenging charges by Cray Research Inc of the United States.

"American officials say that the U.S. market is open...but no Japanese-made supercomputer has ever been sold to the U.S. government, although they were accepted in Europe," an official of the Japan Electronic Industry Development Association (JEIDA) said at a news conference.
During 1993 and 1995, 10 American makers successfully won bids to supply supercomputers to the Japanese government, along with 26 Japanese makers, JEIDA said.

U.S. computer maker Cray Research filed a petition on July 29 with the U.S. Commerce Department and International Trade Commission (ITC) alleging Japan's NEC Corp was selling supercomputers on the U.S. market at less than fair value.
Cray also charged that Japan's government procurement market is virtually closed to foreign supercomputer makers.
JEIDA reiterated its view that Cray's sales had fallen because of sales by other U.S. supercomputer makers, such as International Business Machines Corp and Silicon Graphics Inc.
ITC will make a preliminary determination by September 12 on whether the U.S. industry is being injured by imports of supercomputers from Japan.
